column2: Well, say, Hooker, exclaimed Phil, "you're all right!
column3: Well, say, Hooker, exclaimed Phil, "you're all right!

column2: I didn't suppose you'd stoop to work, even under such circumstances.
column3: I didn't suppose you'd stoop to work, even under such circumstances.

column2: Do you know, lots of times we're liable to misjudge some one until something happens to show us just the sort of a person he is."
column3: Do you know, lots of times we're liable to misjudge some one until something happens to show us just the sort of a person he is."

column2: Yes; I suppose that's right, said Roy.
column3: Yes; I suppose that's right, said Roy.

column2: But he did not look Phil in the eyes.
column3: But he did not look Phil in the eyes.

column2: CHAPTER XV.
column3: CHAPTER fifteen.

column2: PLAIN TALK FROM ELIOT.
column3: PLAIN TALK FROM ELIOT.

column2: How's your cold, Phil?
column3: How's your cold, Phil?

column2: It was Eliot who asked the question, and Springer, pausing with one foot on the academy steps, replied:
column3: It was Eliot who asked the question, and Springer, pausing with one foot on the academy steps, replied:

column2: Oh, it's some bub-better, I think.
column3: Oh, it's some bub better, I think.

column2: Glad to hear it, said Roger, slipping his arm through Springer's. "Come on, let's walk over yonder to the fence.
column3: Glad to hear it, said Roger, slipping his arm through Springer's. "Come on, let's walk over yonder to the fence.

column2: I want to have a little chin with you.
column3: I want to have a little chin with you.

column2: It will be ten minutes yet before school begins."
column3: It will be ten minutes yet before school begins."

column2: Together they walked to the fence at the back of the yard, pausing beneath one of the tall old trees which was putting forth tender green leaves.
column3: Together they walked to the fence at the back of the yard, pausing beneath one of the tall old trees which was putting forth tender green leaves.

column2: Leaning against the fence, the captain of the nine faced his companion.
column3: Leaning against the fence, the captain of the nine faced his companion.

column2: As a rule, he began, "you've been a great enthusiast over baseball, and I didn't think you'd let a slight cold keep you away from practice. Exercise is one of the best remedies for a cold, if a person takes care of himself when he's through exercising."
column3: As a rule, he began, "you've been a great enthusiast over baseball, and I didn't think you'd let a slight cold keep you away from practice. Exercise is one of the best remedies for a cold, if a person takes care of himself when he's through exercising."

column2: I know that, said Phil, poking his toe into an ant's nest and declining to meet Roger's steady, level gaze; "but, really, I--I was feeling pretty rotten, you know, and I didn't have mum-much heart for practice."
column3: I know that, said Phil, poking his toe into an ant's nest and declining to meet Roger's steady, level gaze; "but, really, I-I was feeling pretty rotten, you know, and I didn't have mum much heart for practice."

column2: Yes, said the captain, "I'm afraid that was the principal trouble--you didn't have much heart for it.
column3: Yes, said the captain, "I'm afraid that was the principal trouble-you didn't have much heart for it.

column2: You lost heart in the game, and you haven't braced up yet.
column3: You lost heart in the game, and you haven't braced up yet.

column2: I hardly thought it of you, Phil; I didn't expect you to play the baby."
column3: I hardly thought it of you, Phil; I didn't expect you to play the baby."

column2: The baby! exclaimed Springer resentfully.
column3: The baby! exclaimed Springer resentfully.

column2: Yes; that's just what you've been doing.	Yes; that's just what you've been doing.
column3: true

column2: I made up my mind to speak plainly to you, and I'm going to do so--for your own good.
column3: I made up my mind to speak plainly to you, and I'm going to do so-for your own good.

column2: You've been sulking, old fellow.
column3: You've been sulking, old fellow.

column2: It doesn't pay, Phil; you're hurting yourself far more than any one else."
column3: It doesn't pay, Phil; you're hurting yourself far more than any one else."

column2: I don't think you've got any right to call it sulking, objected Springer in a low tone.
column3: I don't think you've got any right to call it sulking, objected Springer in a low tone.

column2: I own up that I did feel bad about the way things went in that gug-game; but I caught a cold, and I decided to take care of myself in order to get back into my best condition.
column3: I own up that I did feel bad about the way things went in that gug game; but I caught a cold, and I decided to take care of myself in order to get back into my best condition.

column2: Is that the reason why you've been giving Rod Grant the cold shoulder?
column3: Is that the reason why you've been giving Rod Grant the cold shoulder?

column2: I haven't been giving him---- What has he said to you, Eliot?	I haven't been giving him---- What has he said to you, Eliot?
column3: true

column2: Has he been tut-tut-talking about me?"
column3: Has he been tut tut talking about me?"

column2: Not a word.
column3: Not a word.

column2: Then why should you say I'd given him the cold shoulder?
column3: Then why should you say I'd given him the cold shoulder?

column2: It was apparent to the dullest, Phil.	It was apparent to the dullest, Phil.
column3: true

column2: For some time before that game you and Grant were very chummy; you were nearly always together, so that everybody noticed it.
column3: For some time before that game you and Grant were very chummy; you were nearly always together, so that everybody noticed it.

column2: Since the game you've not been together at all, and I, myself, have plainly observed your efforts to avoid him. Now, old man, there can only be one explanation for such conduct: you're sore--sore because he succeeded in holding Barville down after you had failed."
column3: Since the game you've not been together at all, and I, myself, have plainly observed your efforts to avoid him. Now, old man, there can only be one explanation for such conduct: you're sore-sore because he succeeded in holding Barville down after you had failed."

column2: Weakly Springer sought to protest against this, but stopped in the midst of it, fully comprehending how feeble his words were.
column3: Weakly Springer sought to protest against this, but stopped in the midst of it, fully comprehending how feeble his words were.

column2: It's folly, Springer, said Eliot, "sheer childish folly.
column3: It's folly, Springer, said Eliot, "sheer childish folly.

column2: We were all sorry to see you get your bumps and lose control, and I don't believe any one was any sorrier than Grant himself; for, somehow, I've come firmly to believe that he's on the square.
column3: We were all sorry to see you get your bumps and lose control, and I don't believe any one was any sorrier than Grant himself; for, somehow, I've come firmly to believe that he's on the square.

column2: He was reluctant about going on to the slab when I called him."
column3: He was reluctant about going on to the slab when I called him."

column2: Perhaps that was because he was afraid he'd get his, too, muttered Springer.
column3: Perhaps that was because he was afraid he'd get his, too, muttered Springer.

column2: Now, that isn't generous, and you know it.	Now, that isn't generous, and you know it.
column3: true

column2: If the score had been heavy against us at the time, some fellows might have fancied Grant's reluctance was prompted by fear and a disinclination to shoulder another man's load in the first game he pitched.
column3: If the score had been heavy against us at the time, some fellows might have fancied Grant's reluctance was prompted by fear and a disinclination to shoulder another man's load in the first game he pitched.

column2: I've not sized it up as anything of the sort.
column3: I've not sized it up as anything of the sort.

column2: You and he were close friends, and, knowing how you must feel to be batted out, he was loath to go in.
column3: You and he were close friends, and, knowing how you must feel to be batted out, he was loath to go in.

column2: You must realize it was a mighty lucky thing for us that we had a pitcher to take your place.
column3: You must realize it was a mighty lucky thing for us that we had a pitcher to take your place.

column2: Barville had you going, Phil, and you couldn't seem to steady down.
column3: Barville had you going, Phil, and you couldn't seem to steady down.

column2: Even old stagers get into that condition sometimes when pitching, and it's not an infrequent occurrence that a slabman who is not thought so good steps in and stops the slaughter."
column3: Even old stagers get into that condition sometimes when pitching, and it's not an infrequent occurrence that a slabman who is not thought so good steps in and stops the slaughter."

column2: Every-bub-body seems to think Grant is pretty good, mumbled Springer.
column3: Every bub body seems to think Grant is pretty good, mumbled Springer.

column2: He certainly did amazingly well, for which he generously gave you all the credit.
column3: He certainly did amazingly well, for which he generously gave you all the credit.

column2: I suppose he'll be the whole shooting match, now.
column3: I suppose he'll be the whole shooting match, now.

column2: Those words betray you, my boy.	Those words betray you, my boy.
column3: true

column2: You've been trapped by the green-eyed monster.
column3: You've been trapped by the green eyed monster.

column2: Come, come, Phil, you're too manly for that." He put out a hand and rested it on Springer's shoulder.
column3: Come, come, Phil, you're too manly for that." He put out a hand and rested it on Springer's shoulder.

column2: The color mounted into Phil's cheeks and slowly receded, leaving him pale, and still with downcast eyes.
column3: The color mounted into Phil's cheeks and slowly receded, leaving him pale, and still with downcast eyes.

column2: Eliot went on, steadily and earnestly:
column3: Eliot went on, steadily and earnestly:

column2: We need two pitchers--we must have them if we hope to make a decent showing in the series.	We need two pitchers-we must have them if we hope to make a decent showing in the series.
column3: true

column2: By and by we'll have to play two games a week, and some of those games come so close together that one pitcher alone, unless he has an arm of iron, can't do all the flinging.
column3: By and by we'll have to play two games a week, and some of those games come so close together that one pitcher alone, unless he has an arm of iron, can't do all the flinging.

column2: You've been wonderfully successful in coaching Grant, and all the time you were training him to relieve you in a measure when the hardest work should come.
column3: You've been wonderfully successful in coaching Grant, and all the time you were training him to relieve you in a measure when the hardest work should come.

column2: Nobody wants to rob you of any credit; every one says you've done a mighty good turn with him.
column3: Nobody wants to rob you of any credit; every one says you've done a mighty good turn with him.

column2: But if you continue to sulk, as you have for the past few days, you'll lose the sympathy of your teammates; but you won't hurt Grant--otherwise than his feelings."
column3: But if you continue to sulk, as you have for the past few days, you'll lose the sympathy of your teammates; but you won't hurt Grant-otherwise than his feelings."

column2: I don't believe it would hurt his feelings a great deal.
column3: I don't believe it would hurt his feelings a great deal.

column2: Roger was vexed, but he continued to maintain his calm manner.
column3: Roger was vexed, but he continued to maintain his calm manner.

column2: You ought to know him better than any one else around here; you ought to know whether he's at all sensitive or not.	You ought to know him better than any one else around here; you ought to know whether he's at all sensitive or not.
column3: true

column2: I'll tell you honestly, if I were in his place to-day, I'd feel it.
column3: I'll tell you honestly, if I were in his place to day, I'd feel it.

column2: Now, I'm your friend, old fellow, and I want you to listen to me and take my advice.
column3: Now, I'm your friend, old fellow, and I want you to listen to me and take my advice.

column2: Forget it. Get out for practice, treat Grant the same as before, and make up your mind you'll do your level best to redeem yourself in the next game you pitch.
column3: Forget it. Get out for practice, treat Grant the same as before, and make up your mind you'll do your level best to redeem yourself in the next game you pitch.

column2: You'll have plenty of chances to show the stuff you're made of."
column3: You'll have plenty of chances to show the stuff you're made of."

column2: I don't suppose the fellows have much confidence in me now.
column3: I don't suppose the fellows have much confidence in me now.

column2: Nonsense!	Nonsense!
column3: true

column2: Unless they're chumps, they know every pitcher has his off days.
column3: Unless they're chumps, they know every pitcher has his off days.

column2: There'll be a practice game to-night; we'll play against a picked up scrub team.
column3: There'll be a practice game to night; we'll play against a picked up scrub team.

column2: Now, I want to see you at the field in a suit and ready to do your part."
column3: Now, I want to see you at the field in a suit and ready to do your part."

column2: All right, agreed Phil.
column3: All right, agreed Phil.

column2: But later, conscience-stricken and ashamed, he could not bring himself to seek Rodney Grant and own up manfully to his silly behavior.
column3: But later, conscience stricken and ashamed, he could not bring himself to seek Rodney Grant and own up manfully to his silly behavior.

column2: And Grant, having begun to feel piqued, made no further advances.
column3: And Grant, having begun to feel piqued, made no further advances.

column2: At noon that day Roy Hooker returned to school, bringing a written excuse from his mother.
column3: At noon that day Roy Hooker returned to school, bringing a written excuse from his mother.

column2: Having a chance to speak privately with Springer, he said:
column3: Having a chance to speak privately with Springer, he said:

column2: I hear Eliot has expressed his estimation of you and Rod Grant.
column3: I hear Eliot has expressed his estimation of you and Rod Grant.

column2: Phil started.
column3: Phil started.

column2: You can near lots of things, he retorted sharply.
column3: You can near lots of things, he retorted sharply.

column2: The fellows have been talking about it, returned Roy.
column3: The fellows have been talking about it, returned Roy.

column2: They say Eliot has said Grant will make a better pitcher than you, because you lack heart.
column3: They say Eliot has said Grant will make a better pitcher than you, because you lack heart.

column2: It was a blow below the belt, and, in spite of himself, Phil could not help showing the effect.
column3: It was a blow below the belt, and, in spite of himself, Phil could not help showing the effect.

column2: He's welcome to th-think what he chooses, he exclaimed hotly; "it doesn't disturb me."
column3: He's welcome to t h think what he chooses, he exclaimed hotly; "it doesn't disturb me."

column2: Nevertheless, he was so much disturbed that, in spite of his promise to Roger, he was not with the team when it took the field that night for the practice game.
column3: Nevertheless, he was so much disturbed that, in spite of his promise to Roger, he was not with the team when it took the field that night for the practice game.

column2: For he himself had vainly sought to put aside the depressing and unnerving conviction that in steadiness, stamina and self-confidence, Rodney Grant was his superior; something he had determined never to breathe to any one else, but which the keen judgment of the team captain had found out.
column3: For he himself had vainly sought to put aside the depressing and unnerving conviction that in steadiness, stamina and self confidence, Rodney Grant was his superior; something he had determined never to breathe to any one else, but which the keen judgment of the team captain had found out.

column2: Nevertheless, when he reached home by a roundabout course, and found it impossible to dismiss thoughts of the boys engaged in that practice game, he eventually decided that he was a fool.
column3: Nevertheless, when he reached home by a roundabout course, and found it impossible to dismiss thoughts of the boys engaged in that practice game, he eventually decided that he was a fool.

column2: Having reached this conclusion, he set off in great haste for the gymnasium, running the greater part of the distance.
column3: Having reached this conclusion, he set off in great haste for the gymnasium, running the greater part of the distance.

column2: Drawing near the gym, he could hear the boys engaged in the game beyond the high board fence.
column3: Drawing near the gym, he could hear the boys engaged in the game beyond the high board fence.

column2: It did not take him long to shed his outer clothes and get into a baseball suit.
column3: It did not take him long to shed his outer clothes and get into a baseball suit.

column2: The game was in the second inning, with the regular team at bat and Hooker pitching for the scrub, which was made up partly of grammar school boys.
column3: The game was in the second inning, with the regular team at bat and Hooker pitching for the scrub, which was made up partly of grammar school boys.

column2: Everybody seemed to be watching Roy, and Phil walked on to the field and toward one of the benches without attracting attention.
column3: Everybody seemed to be watching Roy, and Phil walked on to the field and toward one of the benches without attracting attention.

column2: Look at Hook! whooped Chipper Cooper.
column3: Look at Hook! whooped Chipper Cooper.

column2: He's actually trying to strike Roger out!
column3: He's actually trying to strike Roger out!

column2: Eliot was at bat, and the umpire had just called the second strike on him.
column3: Eliot was at bat, and the umpire had just called the second strike on him.

column2: There were no runners on the sacks.
column3: There were no runners on the sacks.

column2: He struck aout Tut in t'other innin', drawled Sile Crane.
column3: He struck aout Tut in t'other innin', drawled Sile Crane.

column2: I guess that's got him puffed up some.
column3: I guess that's got him puffed up some.

column2: Apparently not at all discomposed by these remarks, Hooker continued steadily about his business, and presently, rousing a shout of surprise, he succeeded in fanning the captain of the nine.
column3: Apparently not at all discomposed by these remarks, Hooker continued steadily about his business, and presently, rousing a shout of surprise, he succeeded in fanning the captain of the nine.

column2: Roger stepped back from the plate, after striking out, and stood there gazing at Roy, with one of his strange, rare smiles.
column3: Roger stepped back from the plate, after striking out, and stood there gazing at Roy, with one of his strange, rare smiles.

column2: Crane followed.
column3: Crane followed.

column2: Dinged if I wouldn't like ter see him fan me! he said.
column3: Dinged if I wouldn't like ter see him fan me! he said.

column2: A moment later Hooker pulled him handsomely on a wide one, and the first strike was called, Cooper being again awakened to a wondering, whooping state of merriment.
column3: A moment later Hooker pulled him handsomely on a wide one, and the first strike was called, Cooper being again awakened to a wondering, whooping state of merriment.

column2: Look out! look out! shouted the little fellow.
column3: Look out! look out! shouted the little fellow.

column2: He'll get you if you don't.	He'll get you if you don't.
column3: true

column2: Who said Hooky couldn't pitch?
column3: Who said Hooky couldn't pitch?

column2: There's more pitch in him than you can find in a big chew of spruce gum."
column3: There's more pitch in him than you can find in a big chew of spruce gum."

column2: Crane, setting his teeth, made two fouls, and then sent Chipper into real convulsions by whiffing at a high one which Roy whistled across his shoulders with surprising accuracy.
column3: Crane, setting his teeth, made two fouls, and then sent Chipper into real convulsions by whiffing at a high one which Roy whistled across his shoulders with surprising accuracy.

column2: You wanted to see it, yelled Cooper.
column3: You wanted to see it, yelled Cooper.

column2: You got a look, all right. Oh, say!	You got a look, all right. Oh, say!
column3: true

column2: Where did this new Christy Mathewson come from, anyhow?
column3: Where did this new Christy Mathewson come from, anyhow?

column2: Look out for him, Roddy, or he'll add you to his list.
column3: Look out for him, Roddy, or he'll add you to his list.

column2: List' to my warning."
column3: List' to my warning."

column2: Rodney Grant did not strike out, but, nevertheless, he failed to meet one of Hooker's shoots squarely, and the grammar school shortstop gathered in an easy grounder and threw to first for the third put-out.
column3: Rodney Grant did not strike out, but, nevertheless, he failed to meet one of Hooker's shoots squarely, and the grammar school shortstop gathered in an easy grounder and threw to first for the third put out.

column2: Roger Eliot lingered to speak a word to Hooker, and Springer, still unnoticed, plainly heard what he said.
column3: Roger Eliot lingered to speak a word to Hooker, and Springer, still unnoticed, plainly heard what he said.

column2: Perhaps we've made a mistake in sizing you up, Roy, old fellow.	Perhaps we've made a mistake in sizing you up, Roy, old fellow.
column3: true

column2: It's your work alone that has prevented us from scoring in either of these innings.
column3: It's your work alone that has prevented us from scoring in either of these innings.

column2: You've always had speed and curves, but now you seem able to get the pill over.
column3: You've always had speed and curves, but now you seem able to get the pill over.

column2: Keep it up, old fellow, and you'll make a pitcher yet, We may need you before the season ends."
column3: Keep it up, old fellow, and you'll make a pitcher yet, We may need you before the season ends."
